awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Lipid Regulation of Receptor Tyrosine Kinases
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Adam W. Smith from the University of Akron to investigate lipid regulation of receptor tyrosine kinases. The surface of living cells is composed of a lipid membrane embedded with thousands of protein receptors. Dynamic associations between membrane proteins and lipids are integral to function, but resolving these interactions has proven to be extremely challenging. This project applies advanced fluorescence methods, and single-molecule imaging to measure lipid-protein interactions in biological membranes. The long-term goal is to develop a quantitative chemical model for the interface between plasma membrane lipids and a class of membrane proteins called receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs). RTKs are integral membrane proteins that regulate cell growth and differentiation. The focus of this project is on two RTKs, EphA2 and EGFR. Integral with these research objectives is an education and broader impacts program that enhances STEM education at the University of Akron and provides materials and curriculum for enhanced laboratory instruction across the country. This includes the development of a 3D-printable, smartphone spectrometer (the SpecPhone) for implementation in university laboratory courses. The low cost and simplicity of the SpecPhone also make it accessible to K-12 students and citizens so that they can engage in real-world science problems.  The broader impacts work creates new curriculum and teacher training workshops for K-12 STEM education, to participate in local Maker Fairs, and to develop protocols for a transformative citizen science project in the Lake Erie watershed.

Lipids solvate membrane proteins and, in many cases, regulate their activity through direct, specific contacts. Many lipid-protein interactions are inferred from static structures or computer simulations; however, there is little experimental data to verify these interactions in situ and determine their kinetic and thermodynamic stability. This project uses advanced fluorescence methods, including pulsed-interleaved excitation fluorescence cross-correlation spectroscopy (PIE-FCCS) and single-molecule imaging to measure molecular associations in biological membranes. The long-term goal is to develop a quantitative chemical model for the interface between plasma membrane lipids and receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs). Both the extracellular domain (ECD) and the intracellular domain (ICD) of RTKs associate directly with the plasma membrane, but the chemical details of the associations are not well-understood. This project focuses on two RTKs, EphA2 and EGFR. The central hypothesis is that anionic lipids bind these proteins and regulate their structure and activity. To test this hypothesis, we determine the affinity and specificity of anionic lipid binding to EGFR in model supported lipid bilayers. We also investigate the regulation of EphA2 structure and dynamics by anionic lipids in model membranes. Finally, we resolve the functional role of anionic lipid binding to EGFR. Achieving these objectives contributes to a systematic understanding of how the lipid-protein interface is affected by parameters like lipid charge, headgroup structure, solvent pH, and salt effects. The results significantly advance our understanding of the chemical interactions that guide cell communication. Integral with these research objectives is an education and broader impacts program that enhances STEM education at the University of Akron and provides materials and curriculum for enhanced laboratory instruction across the country. This includes the development of a 3D-printable, smartphone spectrometer (the SpecPhone) for implementation in university laboratory courses. The low cost and simplicity of the SpecPhone also make it accessible to K-12 students and citizens so that they can engage in real-world science problems. The focus of the broader impacts work is to create new curriculum and teacher training workshops for K-12 STEM education, to participate in local Maker Fairs, and to develop protocols for a transformative citizen science project in the Lake Erie watershed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project used advanced fluorescence methods to study how lipids regulate the function of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) in cell membranes. The research focused on two specific RTKs, EphA2 and EGFR, which are known to play important roles in cancer development. The project also included educational and outreach components to enhance STEM education and engage the public in scientific inquiry. In one of the most recent publications funded by this grant, we used a time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy method called pulsed-interleaved excitation fluorescence cross-correlation spectroscopy (PIE-FCCS) to examine the assembly of EphA2 in live cells. Their results demonstrated that ligand-free EphA2 assembles into multimers facilitated by two types of interactions in the ectodomain. The first interaction type is a symmetrical interaction that is required for ligand-induced clustering, tumor-suppressive signaling, and suppression of cell migration. The second interaction is an asymmetrical interaction occurring between the amino terminus of one EphA2 and the membrane proximal domain of an adjacent EphA2. This interaction promotes oncogenic signaling, migration in vitro, and tumor invasiveness in vivo. These results help resolve the role of EphA2 multimeric signaling clusters in dictating the functions of EphA2 in oncogenesis.

In additional work funded by the grant, we quantified the binding of anionic lipids, such as PIP2, to peptides. This was demonstrated in model membranes using PIE-FCCS. The study provided direct experimental evidence for the formation of stable complexes between PIP2 and peptides derived from membrane proteins. We also contributed to a study of a novel peptide, PET1, designed to target EGFR in an acidic environment similar to that found in tumors. PET1 was shown to bind to EGFR and inhibit its activation by disrupting the dimerization of the transmembrane domain. PIE-FCCS was also used to investigate the role of lipids in regulating the oligomerization of RTKs. This technique allowed us to measure the concentration, mobility, proximity, and oligomerization state of membrane proteins in live cells. For example, one study showed that EGFR exists as monomers in unstimulated cells but forms multimers upon ligand binding. The project also explored the potential impact of different EGFR mutations on drug sensitivity. This research focused on mutations in exon 19 of EGFR, which are commonly found in lung cancer. The study found that different mutations within exon 19 can lead to varying levels of sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs). This suggests that allele-specific therapies may be necessary to effectively treat patients with these mutations.

The research findings from this project have potential implications for the development of novel cancer therapies. Specifically, the work highlights the importance of targeting lipid-protein interactions as a potential therapeutic strategy. The design of protein-protein interaction compounds like peptides that specifically target RTKs in acidic tumor environments, could lead to more selective and effective cancer treatments. The study of allele-specific differences in drug sensitivity among EGFR mutants could inform the development of personalized therapies for lung cancer. This knowledge could guide clinicians in selecting the most effective TKIs for individual patients. The use of advanced fluorescence techniques, like PIE-FCCS, to study membrane protein interactions could facilitate the discovery of new drug targets and the development of novel therapeutic strategies. This approach could lead to a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying cancer development and progression.

The project also sought to broaden participation and understanding of science through several initiatives. The project provided opportunities for undergraduate students to engage in meaningful research in bioanalytical and biophysical chemistry. Students contributed to several publications arising from the project, gaining valuable experience in laboratory techniques and scientific communication. A 3D-printable, dual-beam spectrophotometer, the SpecPhone, was developed and paired with a smartphone adaptor for data acquisition. This low-cost, open-source instrument allows for accurate and reproducible measurements of visible light absorption, making it ideal for educational settings. This innovation addressed the need for affordable and accessible scientific tools, potentially increasing educational outcomes for students. The SpecPhone was implemented in university laboratory courses, enhancing student learning in spectroscopy. Protocols were also developed for a citizen science project focusing on water quality monitoring in the Lake Erie watershed. The accessibility and portability of the SpecPhone, combined with newly developed protocols, empower citizen scientists to engage in environmental monitoring and contribute to the understanding and protection of this vital ecosystem.

This CAREER Award resulted in significant scientific advancements in understanding the role of lipids in regulating RTK structure and function. The project also demonstrated a commitment to broadening the participation in STEM fields through innovative educational tools, curriculum development, and citizen science initiatives. These efforts fostered a greater understanding and appreciation for science within both academic and community settings.
